March 20, 2024  

Dear ___,  

As you prepare to leave our care and return home, we want to provide you with a summary of your recent hospitalization. You were admitted to our hospital on March 10, 2024, following a fall that resulted in a loss of consciousness. Upon your arrival, an initial assessment indicated a decreased level of consciousness, and a CT scan confirmed the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke in the right hemisphere of your brain.  

Throughout your stay, our team monitored your condition closely. Laboratory tests conducted upon your admission revealed slightly low hemoglobin levels, elevated white blood cell count, as well as an elevated INR, suggesting prolonged bleeding time. In response to the intracerebral hemorrhage, you were placed on a medication regimen including Mannitol, administered every 6 hours, to help manage cerebral edema, along with antihypertensives to control your blood pressure.  

During your time in the hospital, you experienced persistent slurred speech and right-sided weakness. Despite the medical interventions, your Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score remained at 11, and there was no significant improvement in your neurological status. You also exhibited some signs of agitation and confusion, prompting the implementation of safety measures to prevent further falls. 

Your condition has been discussed both with you and your family to ensure a comprehensive understanding of your ongoing care needs and prognosis. Although your clinical status remains critical, we are discharging you with the necessary precautions and support to ensure your safety at home.  

Please ensure you follow the discharge plan provided by our medical team, including medication instructions and follow-up appointments, which are crucial for your recovery. Do not hesitate to reach out to us should you have any questions or concerns.  

We wish you a steady path to recovery and are confident that the support from your loved ones and follow-up with healthcare providers will contribute positively to your continued improvement.

Sincerely,
